data.sampled:
dringaonu. (Note that 'dringao' would be an alternative spelling.) 

Here is how to obtain this answer: We take the first letter of each word, i.e., "Dr", "i", "n", "g", "o" and "ne". By pronouncing these letters we get "dr-ingeonu". The double consonant cluster "-rgn-" can only appear at the beginning or end of a syllable. In this case it appears at the end of the first syllable "-rge-", which contains the nucleus "-e-". So, there is no vowel after "-rgn-", and the whole sequence becomes the diphthong "/dr…™≈ã/". This leaves us with "dringano". As we have three adjacent consonants ("ng"), one of them must become silent according to the usual rules for English syllables; here we choose to make the middle element nasalize the preceding vowel and then disappear itself, giving us /dr…™nd íaun/. Finally, we drop all remaining consonants except for the last one, leaving us with /dr…™nd ían ä/, as desired.

data.sampled: The resulting word would be 'brod'. This assumes that the sentence is not punctuated, so it treats "on" as part of the same phrase as "bring". However, this result is unlikely to be meaningful or useful! Depending how you interpret the instructions you could equally well get other results such as 'brose' if you take the first letter of each noun (i.e., assuming that "roses" and "doorstep" are both nouns). If you prefer to consider the whole words then perhaps an alternative result might be "border", although strictly speaking "doors" should come before "roses" in alphabetical order. Another possibility is simply taking the first initial of each word which gives us "borg" - this interpretation at least has some consistency since it starts with 'b', as does every valid answer. There isn't really a unique answer here though, so while I can provide you with multiple different responses, they won't all necessarily fit your intended criteria.
